title: If I want to convert my Ch 7 to a ch 13 which form do I complete? Do I have to refile all new docs?
question: We filed and court came back that we have to wait a year..so we can convert to a 13,but need to know what forms are needed to submit to courts....
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy trustee,Bankruptcy documents,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Representing yourself
answers: Conversion from chapter 7 to chapter 13 is allowed only on motion. There is no specific form for you to complete. However, there are certain facts that must be pled in the motion. Mainly, you must specify the reason(s) for the conversion and that the case has not been previously converted. The motion must be accompanied by a notice giving all parties in interest the right to object. Keep in mind that the chapter 7 bankruptcy trustee may object to the conversion if your only reason is not wanting to turn over any non-exempt assets for distribution to your creditors. This is quite common around tax time, when debtors realize that they must forego of most or all of their tax refunds to receive discharge. My recommendation is to consult an attorney before filing anything with the court. The second issue is that you would have to file and serve a chapter 13 plan within two weeks from converting your case. This is not an easy task and you would need an attorney for sure. Good luck!

It's a form that you file with the court, (F 3015-1.21.NOTICE.CONVERT.CH13). You have to use the court form. You do not have to file all new documents, but there are a couple things you must file when the case is converted. The notice you get from the court will explain exactly which documents must be filed.

Aside from the motion to convert, you need to update your schedules, do a chapter 13 means test and a chapter 13 plan. While it is possible to represent yourself in a chapter 13, I must agree with the other attorneys and say it is very difficult to get a plan confirmed and get through the 13 process without an attorney. Generally, your attorney is going to get paid through your plan, so if you can fund a chapter 13 plan, you can afford an attorney. Look on AVVO. Call around. There are plenty of competent bankruptcy attorneys in your area. Find one you're comfortable with, and good luck.

BK is not a DIY project. Court statistics confirm that virtually all non-atty assisted Chapter 13 cases fail. Click the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer" and hire/consult with one ASAP. Many offer free consultations.

Converting your case to chapter 13 requires a motion with the court. If you started in chapter 7 and submitted papers saying you were unable to make any payment to your creditors, you will need some documentation to show you are now able to make at least partial payment to your creditors. You will want to look at bankruptcy code section 706.
You need to hire a bankruptcy attorney. Chapter 13 is too difficult to attempt on your own.

You can look at the Court Manual on the court's website at http://www.cacb.uscourts.gov/ to see a list of forms that are required for a Chapter 13. Some of those forms are the same as required for a Chapter 7, in which case they would not need to be re-filed. HOWEVER, while you are on the court website, do yourself a favor and take a look at the court's "2013 Annual Pro Se Report." That report states that for the year 2013 (the most recent year the report covers), 86.9% of all Chapter 13 cases where the debtor represented themselves ("Pro Se") were dismissed prior to confirmation. Only three (3) Pro Se Chapter 13's were confirmed in all of 2013. So, the odds are strongly against you succeeding in your Chapter 13 by yourself. I strongly recommend you consult with and retain a local bankruptcy attorney to handle your Chapter 13 for you, so that you will not waste a lot of your time and money on a case that in all likelihood will end up being dismissed by the Court. Many attorneys will offer a free initial consultation so they can meet with you and review and discuss your situation and how a Chapter 13 works. A Chapter 13 is completely different from a Chapter 7 and is definitely not something you should attempt on your own.
